awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Dynamics and Transport of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current in Drake Passage (cDrake) Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The Southern Ocean, dominated by the huge Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC),  is responding markedly to climate change, being driven by circumpolar winds that have increased over the past  ~30 years, and warming significantly more that the global ocean over the past ~50 years.  Geographically, the Drake passage provides a natural ?chokepoint?  for measuring the time varying transport of the ACC component flows. In turn this provides us with a means of taking the ?pulse? of the Southern Ocean circulation.  

The cDrake field experiment is an IPY project to resolve seasonal to interannual variability of the ACC over a four year period. Using an array of (~40) bottom-moored Current and Pressure-recording Inverted Echo Sounders (CPIES) which measure bottom pressure along with the travel time  of 12kHZ sound pulses to and from the surface, a time series of velocity and temperature profiles over a grid array has been assembled over a 5 year timespan. 

A full analysis of the CPIE and ancillary hydrographic data sets (e.g. CTD, ADCP and XBT) will be undertaken to resolve the ACC transport variability, partition its vertical structure between barotropic and baroclinic components, and its lateral structure partitioned between the many jets and fronts  that comprise the ACC in the Drake Passage.

por.por_cntn:
The Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) is the largest current on the planet. It is an important conduit for transporting mass, heat and freshwater between all the major ocean basins. Its meridional overturning circulation (MOC) is responsible for upwelling deep waters from depths up to 2 kilometers to the sea surface where they come in contact with the atmosphere and exchange heat and anthropogenic carbon. Despite the importance of the ACC and its MOC to the Earth’s climate, measuring its transport and understanding its physics have been hampered by a lack of in situ data that span the entire current system with sufficient temporal and spatial resolution to resolve the variability of the ACC fronts and eddies. This award supported analysis of an unprecedented moored array of Current and Pressure Recording Inverted Echo Sounders (CPIES) and current meter moorings that spanned the entire ACC in Drake Passage for a period of 4 years, 2007-2011, in a field program called cDrake. The analyses yielded important information on this major current system and provided benchmarks for improving numerical models and predictions.

The ACC is a deep-reaching current, with significant near-bottom velocities that are hard to measure because it is difficult to maintain moorings in such a strong current. Annual mean near-bottom currents from cDrake are remarkably stable from year to year. The mean depth-independent or barotropic transport determined from the near-bottom current meter records was 45.6 Sverdrups (1 Sv = 1 million cubic meters per second. Summing the mean barotropic transport with the mean baroclinic transport relative to zero at the seafloor of 127.7 Sv gives a total transport through Drake Passage of 173.3 Sv. Our baroclinic estimate of 127.7 Sv is in agreement with prior measurements that assume zero velocity at the seafloor. The new estimate of the mean total ACC transport of 173.3 Sv is 30% larger than the canonical estimate often used as the benchmark for global circulation and climate models.  The increase is entirely due to including the near-bottom currents.

The ACC is driven by strong year-round eastward winds on an unbroken path around the Antarctic continent. This constant source of momentum must find a sink else the current would accelerate indefinitely. Momentum moves through the fluid via a pressure forcing known as form stress. We used the cDrake observations to constrain a numerical model, the Southern Ocean State Estimate (SOSE), and the SOSE to examine the pathways and spatial distribution of form stress from surface source to topographic sink. We find that 95% of the zonal momentum input via wind stress at the surface is balanced by topographic form stress across ocean ridges, while the remaining 5% is balanced via bottom friction and momentum flux divergences at the boundaries of the analysis domain. While the time-mean zonal wind stress field exhibits a relatively uniform spatial distribution, time-mean topographic form stress concentrates at shallow ridges and across the continents that lie within the ACC latitudes - primarily Kerguelen Plateau, the Macquarie Ridge region, and South America and the Drake Passage fracture zones - as well as across deep basins separated by basin-scale plains.

In addition to providing a pressure forcing on the solid Earth, the turning of ocean currents provides a torque on the Earth. Observed near-bottom currents are strongly topographically steered, and bottom pressure torques grow large where strong near-bottom flows cross steep topography at small angles.  Using the cDrake observations, the mean bottom pressure torque across this Drake Passage transect, 3 to 4 x 10-9 m s-2, exceeds the mean wind stress curl by a factor of 15 to 20. 

ACC eddies are thought to be the primary mechanism for carrying heat across the ACC. We found eddy heat flux to be predominantly poleward in Drake Passage. The new estimates are in good agreement with sparse historical estimates. Drake Passage is one of 4-10 hot spots of eddy-driven exchange along the ACC path that together account for 20% to 70% of the total poleward heat flux across the current, with the balance coming from weak eddy and mean cross- front transport.

 Our observations and analyses have improved the estimate of the mean and time-varying ACC, the major current system of the Southern Ocean. They provide much needed benchmarks for numerical models which presently do not capture the full range of space and time scales required to resolve important ACC physics.

Publications resulting from this 5-year award include 14 peer-reviewed journal articles, 2 Ph.D. dissertations and 14 conference or workshop presentations.

The award contributed to education through support and training of 2 graduate students.
